ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to develop skills regarding spatial awareness, body language interpretation, pickup of social-emotional cues, development of cultural/deaf awareness, etc.
Improved upon the finer details of American Sign Language including grammar, communicative skills, and facial expressions.
My knowledge of ASL and Deaf culture has expanded immensely. I have learned many more signs, including CLs, while also practicing other skills such as fingerspelling and grammar.

I developed skills I learned in the Fall semester during ASL 1. I learned more about how to have a full conversation with someone, and how to tell a complete story with a beginning, middle, and end including a theme.

- Increased ASL proficiency 
- Increased knowledge on Deaf culture

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I had a great experience in ASL1 with the same professor, but I found in ASL2 she taught with a much more aggressive style than the last semester which made it difficult and stressful to learn.

The monotony of the course made it somewhat difficult to want to participate all the time. I think the incorporation of more engaging activities such as games, more group excursions, etc. would benefit future students.

This course expects a lot of outside involvement, which to me, I view as a major positive. I don't always get the best view of the Deaf community through an early class. However, by going outside of the classroom, we can interact with the Deaf and signing community in beautiful ways. I feel like this class has lots of built-in review which lends itself well to learning. I would say a weakness of this course would be the online signing workbook. The class can feel disjointed with this attachment because often, there are signs used in the homework that we don't talk about in class, which can dock your homework grade. Other than that, phenomenal class!
I think it would be more helpful in a better location, it was in a basement and is not fully made for an ASL class to be taught in.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, actually, I have done so already; I would just be sure to tell them not to take it with this professor.
I would. I think ASL is a great language and very fun to learn.

Absolutely. ASL is the best language and community to be a part of here at Yale. The teachers clearly care about the students and their learning. I find myself incorporating sign language into so many parts of my day. Accessibility is critical, and this class is a great way for students to get involved in making the world more friendly through accessibility.
I would encourage another student to take ASL, especially with professor Rubin. She was a great teacher and gave me advice on how to improve my signing.
YES!! Such a good language class
Yes!! Makes you a better person!
